title: Ethiopia: Concerted Effort for Better Employer-Worker Relations
text:
By Fanuel Lakew 
Employment agencies and employers should work in accordance with the law to safeguard employees rights 
The Addis Ababa Labour and Social Affairs Bureau said that all stakeholders are expected to work in accordance with the law for having good relations among employers, employment agencies and employees. The Bureau organized a consultative workshop on Labour and Social Affairs Proclamation No. 632/2001 with employment agencies here yesterday. 
Presenting a paper on problems of local private employment agencies and way forward, Bureau Industry and Professional Safety Process Head Kassa Seyoum said that of the total 242 registered employment agencies, 71 have received license this year and 74 renewed their licences whereas 97 have not renewed. 
"Lack of awareness on the Proclamation and regulations related with labour, dearth of skilled manpower in the sector and capacity limitation to ensure safety of employees are the major challenges facing the sector," he added. 
Kassa also said that the state of holding non-renewed licence and recruiting under 18 for job contrary to the law are among the challenges. Some agencies also do not pay salaries to employees on time. 
He noted that lack of sound monitoring and evaluation system is a weakness observed on government side; thus, all stakeholders have to implement the law and work for the betterment of employer-worker relations. 
Bureau Head Ephrem Gizaw said that the Bureau would sustain its effort to strengthen relations between employers and workers to enable them contribute to the economy relying on skilled labour in the manufacturing and service sectors as the country is building industry led economy. 
He also said that employment agencies and employers should work in accordance with the law to safeguard employees rights like annual leave, salary, safety and other benefits as production and productivity have direct relation with employees affairs. Ethiopia
